content:
The purpose of a Product Improvement Proposal (PIP) is to introduce any major change to Invent Products. This is required in order to balance the need to support new features, use cases, while avoiding accidentally introducing half thought-out interfaces that cause needless problems when changed.

In general, you should create a PIP when you:

- are creating any major new feature, subsystem, or piece of functionality
- are making any change that impacts the public interfaces of the project
- will impact more than one system or other team members
- would like to define a contract or interface between clients or systems
- are adding a new dependency
- are adding or replacing languages or tools to the stack
- are in doubt of whether you should write one

Consider subscribing to` #pip-notifs` slack channel to keep track of and get notifications for proposals and discussions.

# Proposal lifecycle

## Discuss

keep track of and get notifications for proposals and discussions.

# Proposal lifecycle

## Discuss

Most proposals start with an idea. If you have an idea of how Invent Products could improve, we encourage you to open a task in the [DEV project](https://invent.atlassian.net/jira/software/c/projects/DEV/issues/) with a subject starting with [DISCUSS]. This task will allow you to gather early feedback. We encourage you to start a Draft document or share a Google Document in the task. Have a look at and potentially use the PIP template when creating a new proposal in confluence to see what is expected in your document.

## Draft

Anyone is welcome to propose a new Improvement to Invent Products. You will need to request edit access to the Confluence page in order to create your PIP document. You can do so by opening a permission request task in [ADMIN project](https://invent.atlassian.net/jira/core/projects/ADMIN/issues/).

## Vote

est task in [ADMIN project](https://invent.atlassian.net/jira/core/projects/ADMIN/issues/).

## Vote

Once you or someone else feels like there’s a rough consensus on the idea and there’s no strong opposition, you can move your proposal to the Vote phase. For this you will open a new task in the [DEV project](https://invent.atlassian.net/jira/software/c/projects/DEV/issues/) with the subject starting with [VOTE]. Remember to link the two tasks.

tware/c/projects/DEV/issues/) with the subject starting with [VOTE]. Remember to link the two tasks.

The voting has to last at least 72 hours and it’s a good practice to extend this time if most of this period is a weekend. Everybody is encouraged to give +1 and -1 votes. There’s also fractional votes (0.5, -0.99) that allow you to express your view on the discussion without giving an explicit approval/block signal. However, only scrum masters and rocks-tech members have a binding vote. This means that any vote requires at least 3, +1 binding votes to be recognized as passed. In addition, any -1 binding vote will move the proposal back to the Discuss phase in order to address changes.

n, any -1 binding vote will move the proposal back to the Discuss phase in order to address changes.

The vote is a consensus-seeking process, “the goal is not to win votes or come to a unanimous agreement, but rather to ensure that there’s a forum for people to raise and discuss their concerns, and that nobody feels strongly enough to block the group from moving forward. Consensus-seeking emphasizes discussion over enumeration: *Rough consensus is achieved when all issues are addressed, but not necessarily accommodated.*” (quote from Working in Public: The Making and Maintenance of Open Source Software by Nadia Eghbal)

If you want to introduce significant changes to your proposal after it has been accepted you can do so following the same procedure.

## Accepted

to your proposal after it has been accepted you can do so following the same procedure.

## Accepted

Congratulations! Your proposal has been accepted. Next up is breaking down tasks. You should break down tasks on relevant Jira projects. You can optionally group the tasks together in an epic if it consists of multiple steps and you want to be able to track progress for its implementation or share the progress with others. Once issues are created, you can also ask a committer to create a label for your PIP and link all your issues with it for easier searchability.

committer to create a label for your PIP and link all your issues with it for easier searchability.

Now you can start contributing and - more importantly - you can, and probably should, encourage others to contribute to your project. However this is optional and up to your discretion. You can learn how to contribute and communicate  by reading the Contributing guides. *TODO: Link to guides?* Use your imagination and various communication channels for ways to encourage people if you do not already have contributors following your idea. It is advisable that several people work on the PIP so that the knowledge is shared.

## Completed

You should move your PIP to complete after you consider the main bulk of work has been merged to the repository. It is okay to leave open issues for minor follow up tasks like adding additional capabilities or similar.

## Abandoned

open issues for minor follow up tasks like adding additional capabilities or similar.

## Abandoned

PIP may be moved to abandoned if there has been no owner or intention of developing it further for over a year or if the owner decides to abandon it. The latter can happen if the creator decides to refactor PIP into a new PIP for example or if there is a proposal that supersedes the original PIP.

## Motivation

Airflow DAGs combine Invent's products into a single product as a pipeline. We often call it "Day-1 DAG" or "default DAG." The physical location of this DAG is the git repo of an imaginary customer named "Spider." The Day-1 DAG has been developing within this repo for a while. We believe that this is problematic in terms of scalability and sustainability.

## What problem does it solve?

that this is problematic in terms of scalability and sustainability.

## What problem does it solve?

The first problem with making Day-1 DAG improvements directly on Spider is the lack of a reasonable upgrade strategy. Suppose we created a new customer by forking from the Spider repository. Since Day-1 DAG developments are not versioned, we will not know the exact state of the customer. Hence, upgrading the customer code will be cumbersome.

> Info: There is a situation where this example is not valid. The boxes in Day-1 DAG usually run another library. The customer code gets updated when we upgrade a library to the latest version.The problem occurs when someone displaces, removes, or adds a box in the DAG.

The second problem is scalability. In case multiple customers are copied from the Spider code, there are several versions of the DAG we have to maintain.

## Why is this change needed?

ider code, there are several versions of the DAG we have to maintain.

## Why is this change needed?

To make Day-1 DAGs scalable and sustainable, just like our libraries. In this way, we create a more controlled and reliable environment for live customer codes.

## Suggested Implementation

### Specification

We have Airflow DAGs defined under Spider, as Python files. We should abstract them away and users should request them from a service or library when they need them. DAGs should be configurable and editable. So there are three must-haves we have:

- Day-1 DAG should be offered as a service or a library.
- DAG consumed from the service or library should be configurable.
- Customer-specific improvements can be made on DAG

### Distinction Between the Proposed Change and Rocks Library

Rocks is the framework where we define all algorithmic tasks of Invent pipelines. It consists of three things:

he framework where we define all algorithmic tasks of Invent pipelines. It consists of three things:

1. Abstractions for “pipeline” and “pipeline step” concepts
2. Concrete implementations of algorithms as pipeline steps
3. Definitions of Day-1 DAGs as pipelines

So, one could think that pipelines are already defined within rocks. Why do we need another abstraction over it?

What’s missing is a physical Airflow DAG, which is developed using Airflow API (DAGs, Operators, Hooks, and all that stuff). What rocks provides is just a pipeline definition, a text file that specifies which task should run and when.

We need an “agent” that takes this pipeline definition, and generate an Airflow DAG from it.

Besides, Day-1 DAG is not only rocks pipeline. It has boxes in it for other operational duties as well, such as, data transfer and ETL, cloud service management, periodic maintenance jobs, SLA alerting etc.

### Upgrading

nsfer and ETL, cloud service management, periodic maintenance jobs, SLA alerting etc.

### Upgrading

Bumping the version for upgrading the packaged Day-1 Dag would be sufficient in most cases. If a customer made modifications on the dag, its maintainers should consider the conflicts between the current and incoming versions.

### Backward Compatibility

This change is not expected to be backward compatible. Because it is not a change over an existing system, rather a new system itself.

### Usability

The product should be easy to use across Invent. Users should be able to make changes to the DAG.

### Code Generation

This PIP does not aim a “code generator” for customer scripts. Customer projects can be templated with tools like [cookiecutter](https://github.com/cookiecutter/cookiecutter).

### Reference Work

A proof-of-concept implementation can be found at [GitLab](https://gitlab.com/burak.yilmaz/packaged_dag).

### Rejected Ideas

#### DAG Generator

d at [GitLab](https://gitlab.com/burak.yilmaz/packaged_dag).

### Rejected Ideas

#### DAG Generator

An API that facilitates the creation of all kinds of DAGs got considered. This API would provide the ability to create and edit DAGs via the command line. We thought it to be too far-reaching for our primary problems.

#### Analytics Platform

We sketched a graphical user interface where users can manage all analytical processes within Invent, including DAG creation and editing. We thought it to be too far-reaching for our primary problems.

### References

- DAG factory concept from a Netflix engineer
- DAG factory library from Etsy
- Dynamic DAG concept from Astronomer
- An example of workflow generalization
- From Airflow 2020 Summit: Airflow UX

## Motivation

Rocks library is the main product of Invent, in which solutions focused on different areas such as inventory, forecasting, etl, and pricing do exist. Additionally, it is developed by the collaborative effort of individuals from different product teams. This situation has led to the fact that each team is responsible of its sub-package. Despite the advantages of having a single library that contains all products, it introduces a tight coupling in our system, and make our products depend on each other while we expect to be able to release our products independently. This proposal addresses the coupling problem, and proposes solutions to accomplish the purpose of making our products more independent.

## What problem does it solve?

metadata.title: PIP-2 Decoupled Rocks Library and Release Management

content:
s to accomplish the purpose of making our products more independent.

## What problem does it solve?

With this PIP, the coupling level in the rocks library and our release management will be decreased. Precisely, we will be able to use the most recent versions of products in production under the roof,rocks, without depending on other products.

## Why is this change needed?

It is often faced that a failure in one of the products in the system results in intercepting the releasing and deployment of other products, by two aspects:

metadata.title: PIP-2 Decoupled Rocks Library and Release Management

content:
n the system results in intercepting the releasing and deployment of other products, by two aspects:

1. Rocks builds fail and prevent sub-products to be released. This may be caused by either a software defect in the rocks library, or underlying libraries it uses (internal or external). Even the failure is in a different product, other products are affected.
2. Rocks builds pass, but end to end tests fail in any customer. This may be caused by either a software defect, or data related problems. Even the failure is in a different product, other products would not be able to deploy their latest version to the production system of the customer.

This two consequence decreases development pace and our deployment frequency. By this change, teams will not block each other and will be able to deliver their latest features to the customers easier.

metadata.title: PIP-2 Decoupled Rocks Library and Release Management

content:
will not block each other and will be able to deliver their latest features to the customers easier.

> Info: Since rocks is our main product, it is reasonable to expect that the code-base should be deterministic. In other words, rocks master branch should be built successfully  in any time.  Therefore, it is not suggested to change rocks builds.

## Suggested Implementation

### Specification

The proposed implementation mainly does not effect the code in the production. It is about how we deploy and maintain them. There are three aspects of this improvement proposal:

1. Sub-library installation management
2. Build, release, and deployment process
3. End-to-end test process

#### Sub-library installation management

Currently, our system in the production installs the internal packages separately [1].

metadata.title: PIP-2 Decoupled Rocks Library and Release Management

content:
n management

Currently, our system in the production installs the internal packages separately [1].

In build time, latest versions (9999) of the internal packages are installed [2]. Unit and integration tests use these versions. When the build is successful, a new version of rocks is released.

In production, the versions of these packages are controlled through internal-packages.lock file [3]. In principle, if the customer has a successful end-to-end test, internal-packages.lock file is updated with the most recent versions.

However, since these packages are direct dependencies of the rocks they should be installed as any other requirement would be. And we should specify their versions in the setup configuration (the location may be requirements.txt or setup.cfg). This would also prevent the version conflicts between the libraries. The prerequisite of this is to store the internal packages in a private pypi registry, or find a way out.

metadata.title: PIP-2 Decoupled Rocks Library and Release Management

content:
rerequisite of this is to store the internal packages in a private pypi registry, or find a way out.

Therefore, following tasks should be done within the scope of sub-library installation management

1. Figure out the way to store the install packages in a remote registry. Options: private pypi registry, git, pypi extra_index, etc.
2. Install internal packages as rocks dependency while installing the rocks. Specify the internal packages and their versions in the setup configuration files.

#### Build, release, and deployment process

metadata.title: PIP-2 Decoupled Rocks Library and Release Management

content:
es and their versions in the setup configuration files.

#### Build, release, and deployment process

Build process play an essential role in the entire system. The build process should pass the tests, and release the new rocks version including the internal packages and their versions. Since rocks contains multiple sub-packages, we should be able to manage their dependencies and versions separately. This  leads to packaging and distributing sub-packages independently, which is allowed by namespace packages[4]. By using namespace packages, we can continue maintaining our code in a mono-repo ecosystem, and distribute sub-packages independently.

In namespace packages, each subpackage should have its own setup configuration and requirements.

```
rocks
--- rocks/noob
    --- setup.py
    --- requirements.txt
--- rocks/opal
    --- setup.py
    --- requirements.txt
--- rocks/rocket
    --- setup.py
    --- requirements.txt
--- setup.py
--- requirements.txt
```

metadata.title: PIP-2 Decoupled Rocks Library and Release Management

content:
txt
--- rocks/rocket
    --- setup.py
    --- requirements.txt
--- setup.py
--- requirements.txt
```

Below is the pseudo-process of the rocks builds. It follows a staged build approach, where each sub-package is tested and built independently. This would also require a semantic versioning for each sub-package.

#### End-to-end test process

metadata.title: PIP-2 Decoupled Rocks Library and Release Management

content:
registry

---

For more clarification, please see the example in [5].

#### End-to-end test process

After a successful rocks build, all a customer should know is the rocks version they use (by internal-packages.lock). Rocks packages will know their internal package requirements. However, this is not enough to start using it on the production. Passing unit and integration tests is only sufficient for creating a release. There are non-negligible external factors which, such as the data to run the pipelines on. Therefore, we run the end-to-end tests. However, since the system consists of many independent parts, each of them should be tested in their namespace and they should not block each other. For example, noob can fail the end-to-end tests, but rocket could be successful. This should not prevent rocket part to use the latest rocks release. In this case, noob should not use the last version of its. This should be controlled by constraint files.

metadata.title: PIP-2 Decoupled Rocks Library and Release Management

content:
is case, noob should not use the last version of its. This should be controlled by constraint files.

Below is the pseudo-process of end-to-end tests:

1. Run ETL
2. Run Noob. If pass:update noob library version in constraint fileupdate rocks.noob library version (if we use namespace packages) in internal-packages.lock
3. Run Rocket. If pass:update rocket library version in constraint fileupdate rocks.rocket library version (if we use namespace packages) in internal-packages.lock
4. If any of the steps succeeded, upgrade rocks version in internal-packages.lock

metadata.title: PIP-2 Decoupled Rocks Library and Release Management

content:
rnal-packages.lock
4. If any of the steps succeeded, upgrade rocks version in internal-packages.lock

This scenario solves the dependency between the products, however it is still error-prone. For example, if noob changes it is public interface (e.g. forecast output location) and its consumer, rocket, does not update its code accordingly, rocket tests will be failed. Therefore, noob will be able to increase its version while rocket can’t. Additionally, the new version of noob will keep breaking the rocket. A suggestion to this problem would be to increase versions in internal-packages.lock and constraint file after all tests are successful. However, this will still keep the products dependent even when they have independent internal problems since we will not be aware of the reason of the failure in runtime.

We could add a separate API compliance test before e2e tests to detect interface related errors, and keep incrementing package versions independently.

1. Using a private pypi registry and accessing it through multiple places might be challenging (local, jenkins machines, emr, etc.)
2. Namespace packages would probably end up with multiple wheels. It might be complex to maintain installation steps.
3. Namespace packages require a semantic versioning for each subpackage. We probably will not be able to use pbr.
4. Independent end-to-end tests that change the public API would break other products and yet be able to deploy erroneous versions.
5. warp library is always been considered as the core library on python and pyspark side. Therefore, noob, rocket, and others use warp as their dependency as well. So, determining and specifying warp version on the rocks library could be tricky. We might consider adding warp to add dependencies of noob, rocket etc, and let the pip resolver try to handle the possible conflicts.

metadata.title: PIP-2 Decoupled Rocks Library and Release Management

content:
add dependencies of noob, rocket etc, and let the pip resolver try to handle the possible conflicts.
6. Letting pip resolver handle the possible conflicts is error prone. We might need to add protective steps to build lifecycle. Additionally, teams should be in sync of their dependencies. (i.e. if noob depends on pandas < 1.0 but rocket requires pandas > 1.0, there will be conflict and rocks installation would be failed)

### Backwards Compatibility

This proposal does not effect the code side, and not necessarily have to be backward compatible. Any customer using rocks library should be encouraged to use the new system. However, if we want to make it backward compatible, we can specify internal packages as extras [8]

### Usability

Users should be able to install and maintain rocks and the other underlying libraries easily by one command:

```
pip install invent_rocks
```

or

```
pip install invent_rocks invent_rocks.opal invent_rocks.rocket
```

install invent_rocks
```

or

```
pip install invent_rocks invent_rocks.opal invent_rocks.rocket
```

Each sub-package and top-level rocks has its own setup.py, _version.py, and requirements.txt. They are packaged separately, but after installation, they act like a single rocks library.

# Motivation

I think we should have a data validation system that validates if a sample data is following Invent Data Requirements. Over a web API customer can validate its data itself.

# What does it solve

nvent Data Requirements. Over a web API customer can validate its data itself.

# What does it solve

1. Faster Project InitializationAt the beginning of each project, we waste weeks of our precious time validating if the sample data that is sent by the customer is valid. We can automate this.
2. More stable data validationFor each project, project members are trying to figure out if the data is valid by using their own scripts and know-how. We can make it the same and better for every project.
3. (a maybe benefit) Easier to force the customer to stick to Invent Data RequirementMaybe, this way we can force our customers to provide the data according to our structure more easily. I am not sure this works in real life.

# Why Needed

Because we are doing the same manual controls (not the same actually see #2 above) over and over.

# Suggested Implementation

Two alternatives based on discussions on the Jira task. The details are below.

ested Implementation

Two alternatives based on discussions on the Jira task. The details are below.

For both alternatives, we should have a Processor service that is doing the actual job (validation). We can decide how to do that part in the actual implementation phase. In the Jira discussion, [https://greatexpectations.io/](https://greatexpectations.io/) is suggested as an option.

## Alternative1 - Using RESTful API

- RESTful
- Validations run async

## Alternative2 - Using S3 drops

## Reference Implementation

I’ve actually pushed a demo project on [https://gitlab.com/invent-analytics/data-validator-demo](https://gitlab.com/invent-analytics/data-validator-demo)

This is a very basic sample web project that validates duplications or null values on a tiny CSV file. Only does validation for *product* data and looks for columns *ProductCode* and *ProductDescription*. It is very basic as I said before, and also very dummy.

#### Basic Walkthrough To Run Example Project

is very basic as I said before, and also very dummy.

#### Basic Walkthrough To Run Example Project

After cloning the project:

```
docker-compose build
```

```
docker-compose up
```

Web API should be working. Now create some dummy sample files by:

```
python file-generator/file-generator.py --path miniodata/files
```

And now you have an environment where sample files are uploaded into minio (s3 like environment) bucket and you have a running Web API. Can try using end-points on swagger on:

[http://localhost:6543/api/doc](http://localhost:6543/api/doc)

This way you can test end-points.

#### Disclaimer

Please don’t mind the technology choices and implementation details of the example project because I can also talk for hours about why they shouldn’t be chosen that way  Those are not my choices at all, I’ve just adapted a project that I’ve seen within several hours.
Additionally, although I’ve tried them myself, some end-points or operations may be broken or dysfunctional. But still, I think it gives an idea.

The current structure of the Demand Planning table is in the form of a single table merged with product and warehouse master tables, and this structure supports only one language. We need to migrate to a new multi-language structure that is solved the wishes of our customers.

This task was created to discuss whether the solutions produced for the problem are at an acceptable level in terms of performance and accessibility.

The three tables, named product, warehouse, demand planning was created from the existing single table, and new rows for different languages ​​are added to represent each entity with the lang column on the product and warehouse tables. In use, the entities with wanted language are filtered and these tables are combined to reach the final data. This solution causes an increase in query times compared to the existing structure. The output created by running the widely used reduce queries for two different environments is as follows:

### Large Instance

metadata.title: PIP-6 Performance test for multiple language structure on BigQuery

content:
ing the widely used reduce queries for two different environments is as follows:

### Large Instance

##### Environments:

- Product table includes 15664 * 3 (lang) rows
- Warehouse table includes 4336 * 3 (lang) rows
- Demand Planning table includes  2 billion rows
- Demand Planning Flat table includes 2 billion rows (w/product,warehouse)

## Motivation

Here at invent, we develop many python libraries and as the final product, we combine all these algorithmic or utility libraries (warp, rocket, noob etc.) under the main library, namely rocks. However, we don’t have a infrastructure to manage the dependencies of these libraries. This PIP addresses the dependency management problem and proposes a solution to manage the dependency between our libraries.

## What problem does it solve?

metadata.title: PIP-4 Rocks Internal Library Dependency Management

content:
proposes a solution to manage the dependency between our libraries.

## What problem does it solve?

With this PIP, the dependency management of the libraries will be solved. Rocks will specify the internal libraries and their versions it depends in its setup configuration. Not limited to rocks, other libraries such as rocket and noob should also specify their dependencies. Therefore, we would be able to install rocks with its dependencies and its dependent versions easier.

Another benefit is that we would be able to directly install the packages using a package manager (e.g. pip) instead of downloading from s3 and installing.

## Why is this change needed?

metadata.title: PIP-4 Rocks Internal Library Dependency Management

content:
age manager (e.g. pip) instead of downloading from s3 and installing.

## Why is this change needed?

Now, we install the packages separately in our production system, with their latest versions or their specified versions using a lockfile. For example, to be able to use rocks, one should install warp, noob, and rocket separately. This leads to that conflicting dependencies of these packages might override each other and the final package versions depend on the order of installation of these internal packages. For example, if noob requires pandas == 0.25.0, it will be installed. A later rocket installation requiring pandas >= 0.25 would install pandas 1.0 and this would damage the noob dependency.

Another aspect is that one rocks user should only be aware of the rocks version (s)he uses. The specified rocks version should know which warp,noob,rocket version it depends on.

## Suggested Implementation

### Specification

#### Dependency Management

## Suggested Implementation

### Specification

#### Dependency Management

Currently, our system in the production installs the internal packages separately [1].

In build time, latest versions (9999) of the internal packages are installed [2]. Unit and integration tests use these versions. When the build is successful, a new version of rocks is released.

In production, the versions of these packages are controlled through internal-packages.lock file [3]. In principle, if the customer has a successful end-to-end test, internal-packages.lock file is updated with the most recent versions.

a successful end-to-end test, internal-packages.lock file is updated with the most recent versions.

However, since these packages are direct dependencies of the rocks they should be installed as any other requirement would be. And we should specify their versions in the setup configuration (the location may be requirements.txt or setup.cfg). This would also prevent the version conflicts between the libraries. The prerequisite of this is to store the internal packages in a private pypi registry, or find a way out.

Therefore, following tasks should be done within the scope of sub-library installation management

### Challenges

There are three foreseen challenges:

1. Using a private pypi registry and accessing it through multiple places might be challenging (local, jenkins machines, emr, etc.)
2. warp library is always been considered as the core library on python and pyspark side. Therefore, noob, rocket, and others use warp as their dependency as well. So, determining and specifying warp version on the rocks library could be tricky. We might consider adding warp to add dependencies of noob, rocket etc, and let the pip resolver try to handle the possible conflicts.
3. Letting pip resolver handle the possible conflicts might be error prone. We might need to add protective steps to build lifecycle. Additionally, teams should be in sync of their dependencies. ## Motivation

Rocks library is the main product of Invent, in which solutions focused on different areas such as inventory, forecasting, etl, and pricing do exist. Additionally, it is developed by the collaborative effort of individuals from different product teams. This situation has led to the fact that each team is responsible of its sub-package. Despite the advantages of having a single library that contains all products, it introduces a tight coupling in our system, and make our products depend on each other while we expect to be able to release our products independently. This proposal addresses the coupling problem, and proposes solutions to accomplish the purpose of making our products more independent.

## What problem does it solve?

s to accomplish the purpose of making our products more independent.

## What problem does it solve?

With this PIP, the coupling level in the rocks library and our release management will be decreased. Precisely, we will be able to use the most recent versions of products in production under the roof, rocks, without depending on other products.

## Why is this change needed?

It is sometimes faced that a failure in one of the products in the system results in intercepting the releasing and deployment of other products. Rocks builds fail and prevent sub-products to be released. This may be caused by either a software defect in the rocks library, or underlying libraries it uses (internal or external). Even the failure is in a different product, other products are also affected.

internal or external). Even the failure is in a different product, other products are also affected.

This two consequence decreases development pace and our deployment frequency. By this change, teams will not block each other and will be able to deliver their latest features to the customers easier by having independent versions under rocks.

## Suggested Implementation

### Specification

To release new rocks version, The build process should pass the tests, and release the new rocks version including the internal packages and their versions. Since rocks contains multiple sub-packages, we should be able to manage their dependencies and versions separately. This leads to packaging and distributing sub-packages independently, which is allowed by namespace packages[1]. By using namespace packages, we can continue maintaining our code in a mono-repo ecosystem, and distribute sub-packages independently. By this way, we would end up having different packages for each sub-package.

packages independently. By this way, we would end up having different packages for each sub-package.

In namespace packages, each subpackage should have its own setup configuration and requirements.

```
rocks
--- rocks/noob
    --- setup.py
    --- requirements.txt
    --- _version.py
--- rocks/opal
    --- setup.py
    --- requirements.txt
    --- _version.py
--- rocks/rocket
    --- setup.py
    --- requirements.txt
    --- _version.py
--- setup.py
--- requirements.txt
--- _version.py
```

Below is the pseudo-process of the rocks builds. It follows a staged build approach, where each sub-package is tested and built independently. This would also require a semantic versioning for each sub-package.

---

Obtain latest versions of internal packages (warp, rocket, noob) and their version information (e.g. noob-0.3.22)

versions of internal packages (warp, rocket, noob) and their version information (e.g. noob-0.3.22)

1. Staged testsCommon (rocks package {rocks_core?} )LintUnit TestIntegration TestIf fail, build fails.Noob (rocks_noob subpackage)LintUnit TestIntegration TestNoob docsBuildincrement noob library version in rocks_noob dependencies. commit it in rocks/noob/requirements.txtbuild a new version of rocks_noob.Rocket (rocks_rocket subpackage)LintUnit TestIntegration TestRocket docsBuildincrement rocket library version in rocks_rocket dependencies. commit it in rocks/rocket/requirements.txtbuild a new version of rocks_rocket.Opal (rocks_opal package)LintUnit TestIntegration TestOpal docsBuildincrement warp library version in rocks_opal dependencies. commit it in rocks/opal/requirements.txtBuild a new version of rocks_opal
2. ReleaseDeploy the packages (rocks, rocks_noob, rocks_rocket, rocks_opal) to registry

---

For more clarification, please see the example in [2].

### Challenges

rocks_opal) to registry

---

For more clarification, please see the example in [2].

### Challenges

There are two foreseen challenges:

1. Namespace packages would probably end up with multiple wheels. It might be complex to maintain installation steps.
2. Namespace packages require a semantic versioning for each subpackage. We probably will not be able to use pbr.

### Backwards Compatibility

This proposal does not effect the code side, and not necessarily have to be backward compatible. In fact, since we distribute the packages, it will not be backward compatible. However, if we want to make it backward compatible, we should maintain a second setup mechanism which packages the entire rocks library as a whole and deploy it.

### Usability

Users should be able to install and maintain rocks and the other underlying libraries easily by one command:

```
pip install invent_rocks.noob
```

or

```
pip install invent_rocks invent_rocks.opal invent_rocks.rocket
```

ll invent_rocks.noob
```

or

```
pip install invent_rocks invent_rocks.opal invent_rocks.rocket
```

### Reference or PoC Implementation

A PoC of building sub-packages separately could be seen in [staged-build-with-requirements](https://gitlab.com/eren.sahin/rocks/-/tree/staged-build-with-requirements) branch of the fork of rocks library.

Each sub-package and top-level rocks has its own setup.py, _version.py, and requirements.txt. They are packaged separately, but after installation, they act like a single rocks library.

nts.txt. They are packaged separately, but after installation, they act like a single rocks library.

Please see the [Makefile](https://gitlab.com/eren.sahin/rocks/-/blob/staged-build-with-requirements/Makefile) for build commands, [Jenkinsfile](https://gitlab.com/eren.sahin/rocks/-/blob/staged-build-with-requirements/Jenkinsfile) for build process, and package level details for [rocks](https://gitlab.com/eren.sahin/rocks/-/tree/staged-build-with-requirements), [rocks.noob](https://gitlab.com/eren.sahin/rocks/-/tree/staged-build-with-requirements/rocks/noob), [rocks.opal](https://gitlab.com/eren.sahin/rocks/-/tree/staged-build-with-requirements/rocks/opal), and [rocks.rocket](https://gitlab.com/eren.sahin/rocks/-/tree/staged-build-with-requirements/rocks/rocket).

After a complete build, the resulting packages are as below:

build-with-requirements/rocks/rocket).

invent_rocks.opal-0.2.3.dev367-py3-none-any.whl
invent_rocks.rocket-0.2.3.dev367-py3-none-any.whl

### Considered Alternatives / Rejected Ideas

#### Package Level Staged Builds

If we find the proposed build system, quite complex, another approach would be to manage subpackage dependencies separately. This could be handled by setup.py and setup.cfg files. For example, dask [3] and airflow [4] could be examined. We can still follow a staged test approach here, where each subpackage (e.g. rocks/rocket,…) and their library dependencies (e.g. rocket, noob, etc.) is tested independently.

Below is the pseudo-progress of builds:

---

ies (e.g. rocket, noob, etc.) is tested independently.

Below is the pseudo-progress of builds:

---

1. Obtain latest versions of internal packages (warp, rocket, noob) and their version information (e.g. noob-0.3.22)
2. Staged testsCommonLint → Unit Test → Integration Test → If fail, build fails.NoobLint → Unit Test → Integration Test → DocsIf pass: increment noob library version in requirementsRocketLint → Unit Test → Integration Test → DocsIf pass: increment rocket library version in requirementsOpalLint → Unit Test → Integration Test → DocsIf pass: increment warp library version in requirementsPrepare requirements or setup configuration fileIf noob is passed, increment noob library version in requirementsIf rocket is passed, increment rocket library version in requirementsIf opal is passed, increment warp library version in requirementsAuto-commit the file to master branch.
3. ReleaseDeploy the package (rocks) to registry

---

irementsAuto-commit the file to master branch.
3. ReleaseDeploy the package (rocks) to registry

---

> Info: Note: This approach is alright to protect rocks library against a defect caused by the underlying libraries (noob, warp etc.), however, it is possible to deploy vulnerable code. Because, if any of the subpackages pass, all of them will be deployed with their latest version since the subpackages are not versioned. Therefore, teams will be responsible to keep their master branch always up-to-date and ready-to-go.

This suggestion is rejected since it is error-prone and might lead to deploying unstable code.

# Motivation

The data-requirements document defines the expected data format from customers, and the data-feed process expects input tables in this format. When a change is required in these tables, the relevant data-feed module is also changed. These modules are not customer specific, so all customers are affected from the changes. However, since the way customers send data is not changed for such reasons, the changes made in the document pose a problem for live customers.

is not changed for such reasons, the changes made in the document pose a problem for live customers.

For example there is a table t in data-requirements with columns a, b and c. Customer X sends this table as requested. At some point we change the table and add/remove/rename a column. For sake of simplicity, let’s say we renamed b column as b_2. Customer X will not change the table it sent but our data-feed module now expects b_2 column in table t.

# Suggested Implementation

## Specification

### Current Data Flow

pre-etl: customer specific ETL process that converts data from customer format into data-requirements format.

data-feed: generic ETL process that converts data from data-requirements format into Invent’s internal format.

### Proposed Data Flow

t converts data from data-requirements format into Invent’s internal format.

### Proposed Data Flow

data-requirements migrator: generic ETL process that handles the change in the data-requirements, i.e. the difference between the data requested from client in the conceptual design, and the latest version of the data-requirements. Note that the data requested from client in the conceptual design is also an old version of data-requirements.

## Challenges

Proposed solution does not cover every potential change in data-requirements. Some of them are not possible. For example, if we add a required and not-null column to data-requirements, we can not just add this column in the data-requirements migrator.

null column to data-requirements, we can not just add this column in the data-requirements migrator.

Another problematic case is to make a change that requires data from another table. This is a case that can be coded, but it can be complicated to read another data whose version is unknown. For example, we have added `price_without_tax` column to price table. At the same table there is a `price_with_tax` column, and at the tax_rates table, there is a `tax_rate` column. So, we can get `price_without_tax` information using both table, however, we don’t know the version of tax_rates table, and it is not feasible to cover all versions.

## Backwards Compatibility

Current versions of each table will be considered as initial version, v0. Also the latest versions of each table are v0 for now because there are no changes yet. Therefore, data-requirements migrator will migrate each table from v0 to v0, which means it will not change any table until a change in data-requirements is committed. So it is backwards compatible.

## Implementation

Versions of table t:

| v0initial version | v1rename b → b_2 | v2remove c | v3add d |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| a | a | a | a |

Sample migrator code for table t:

```py
def migrate_t(df: DataFrame, version: str):
    # v0 -> v1
    # rename b -> b_2
    if version == "v0":
        df = df.withColumnRenamed("b", "b_2")
        version = "v1"

    # v1 -> v2
    # remove c
    if version == "v1":
        df = df.drop("c")
        version = "v2"

    # v2 -> v3
    # add d
    if version == "v2":
        df = df.withColumn("d", F.lit(None))
        version = "v3"

    if version == "v3":
        return df
    else:
        raise Exception(f"unknown version {version}")
```

noteIf Customer X wants to take advantage of a new feature that requires column d, we will ask the table t in latest format, v3. Because if customer just adds the new column table will have `a, b, c and d` columns, but this is a different format from all versions. So, they should send `a, b_2 and d `columns. When the customer changes the format, we just change the version in the config file from v0 to v3.

nfig file from v0 to v3.

## Considered Alternatives / Rejected Ideas

### Customer Specific pre-etl

A customer specific script that implements the change in the data-requirements can be added simply, but this change must be done at the same time with data-requirements & data-feed changes, also we have to use new version of rocks immediately for the customer. Thus, it is not as simple as it seems. Besides, even if it were that simple, this process would have to be done for all live customers at the same time, definitely not scalable.

### Backwards Compatible data-feed

Relevant data-feed module can be changed backwards compatible. In other words, the module works in the same way when input data format is any version of the data-requirements. For a simple column rename example in the motivation part, the module produces same output when the name of the column is b or b_2. This approach complicates the data-feed module and gives it another responsibility.

## Motivation

[Rocks library](https://gitlab.com/invent-analytics/sparky/rocks) has started as a collection of our spark jobs, scripts to be executed on spark clusters, therefore you can see that PySpark is ingrained everywhere in it (for instance, base classes initializing a SparkSession as a first thing). For a repository residing in the [Sparky](https://gitlab.com/invent-analytics/sparky) group, it should surprise nobody. However, with (not so) recent developments in the Rocks like [pipeline.py](https://gitlab.com/invent-analytics/sparky/rocks/-/blob/master/rocks/pipeline.py) have made it the main source for our entire product pipelines. But even though our pipelines consist mostly of spark jobs, it has other jobs in them too, most prominently, Linear Programming/Optimization jobs. As it goes, we can expect to have our pipelines contain a higher percentage of non-spark jobs.

jobs. As it goes, we can expect to have our pipelines contain a higher percentage of non-spark jobs.

We want to be able to include non-spark jobs in Rocks not only to benefit from its pipeline optimization capability, but also to be able to use its data-access, utility and testing suites. For this purpose, we propose to introduce another layer of abstraction (as in base classes) to Rocks. We also will need to adapt our pipeline operations to handle non-spark jobs inheriting the new abstractions.

## What problem does it solve?

operations to handle non-spark jobs inheriting the new abstractions.

## What problem does it solve?

Rocks has became the location for every single step our product pipelines may have, but as it stands it isn’t compatible with anything non-spark. For example, our base classes instantiate Spark Sessions, which would be not optimal in any task non-spark related to say the least. Also our pipeline operations require tasks to specify certain properties like, application_args or dependencies, but notwhere to run them(because they are assumed to be ran in spark clusters), which could be different in non-spark cases.

## Why is this change needed?

ran in spark clusters), which could be different in non-spark cases.

## Why is this change needed?

- With the already accepted PIP-1, we will have an easier time to include a task/step, while having it maintainable across all our customers. But we will also require our tasks to be Rocks tasks. So it is important to be able to put a non-spark task in Rocks.
- Since our development efforts has focused on Rocks in the last year, this repo has a better backbone than most of our repos, if not all. Even some external effort in warp.config has been developed with Rocks and its module hierarchy in mind. When we want to apply what we learned and what we developed so far to non-spark jobs, we need to (unnecessarily) replicate the same stuff in other repos. (example, lots of similarities with Rocks needed to be repeated)

# Motivation

In the current structure, we expect and consume only the columns that are specified in the [invent_data_requirement](https://metadata-ui.inventanalytics.com/data/invent_data_requirements.docx) document, but customers might need extra data to be consumed for reporting or other purposes. Some of those data are domain-specific and there are unlimited variations for the content and names for this kind of data. For instance, if the customer uses data for packaging size, varied columns like box, can, bottle, case, pallet, package etc. can be received as crucial data from the customer. Adding all of them to the data requirements document isn’t a feasible and manageable solution. In this proposal, some solution options are suggested in order to handle this kind of data with the current structure.

## Suggestion-III

### Specification

In this suggestion, the main table and its extended_table will be received separately from the customer. In our internal structure, we will generate extended_columns_master and extended tables for all tables that the customer has sent. extended_columns_master table will provide a fixed structure in internal storage for the external tables. In the tables structure section, it can be seen how the extended_columns_master table manages a fixed schema structure for internal data.

The difference is that suggestion IV doesn’t target generating a fixed schema structure for all customers. ## Problem Description

Optimization modules are located in 3 different repos which are Rocket, Rocks and Enigma. As a result, even a small development task may require changes in all these 3 repos. This situation not only leads to a complex development process, but also may causes failures in production.

## Optimization flow

Let's take a brief look at the optimization flow in Rocket DAG:

## Optimization flow

Let's take a brief look at the optimization flow in Rocket DAG:

- optimization_prep is a rocks module and use rocket methods just like the other rocket modules in rocks.
- get_solution is also a standard rocks module.
- On the other hand, optimization module has a rocks-like structure with its data-access class and config.yaml, but located in enigma. This is mainly because of rocks being the home library for just pyspark modules.

[rocks.rocket.optimization_prep](https://gitlab.com/invent-analytics/sparky/rocks/-/blob/master/rocks/rocket/optimization_prep.py)

1. Read optimization inputs
2. Control input
3. Filter all inputs with valid shipment relation scope via rocket.optimization.prep.allocation methods. (If there isn’t any valid shipment_type - ids_relation match for an item-destination pair, then the pair will be removed from all inputs)
4. Save data in dict format via rocket.util.io.save_msgpack method.

metadata.title: PIP-11 Reduce complexity in Rocket optimization structure

content:
will be removed from all inputs)
4. Save data in dict format via rocket.util.io.save_msgpack method.

[enigma.problem.allocation (optimization module)](https://gitlab.com/invent-analytics/optimization/enigma/-/blob/master/enigma/problem/allocation/allocation.py)

1. Read outputs of optimization_prep via rocket.util.io.read_msgpack method.
2. Create variables & constraints, generate problem.
3. Send problem, then get solution from gurobi server, save to invent-gurobi-results bucket via rocket.optimization.gurobi_solver_service methods.

- Includes config.yaml especially for data access layer, just like a rocks module.

[rocks.rocket.get_solution](https://gitlab.com/invent-analytics/sparky/rocks/-/blob/master/rocks/rocket/get_solution.py)

1. Read solution from invent-gurobi-results bucket.
2. Save solution to client bucket.

As you can see above, optimization scripts are unfortunately in everywhere. The complexity can be shown with following development issue in more detail:

tunately in everywhere. The complexity can be shown with following development issue in more detail:

What has to be done in order to add new constraints?

1. Prepare necessary inputs for the new constraint. Hence, firstly add prep methods to rocket.optimization.prep.allocation.
2. Add enable_new_constraint parameter to both rocks and enigma configs.
3. Import and use new rocket.optimization.prep.allocation methods in rocks.rocket.optimization_prep with if-else statement depending on the constraint is active or not.
4. Add read method to enigma.problem.allocation.data_access for new constraint inputs.
5. Add variables and constraint, then modify objective with if-else statements again in enigma.problem.allocation.allocation class.

metadata.title: PIP-11 Reduce complexity in Rocket optimization structure

content:
, then modify objective with if-else statements again in enigma.problem.allocation.allocation class.

To sum up, in order to add new constraint, there has to be changes on many points in all 3 repos. This means at least 3 separate merge requests to be reviewed. Besides, there will be two source of truth to determine whether the constraint is active or not, which are rocks and enigma configs. Moreover, the merge order is also very important to prevent a failure in production as mentioned below.

How Optimization module works and related version issue

a failure in production as mentioned below.

How Optimization module works and related version issue

Rocket, Warp and Enigma packages are[installed into gurobi-server/optimization user with ssh connection as a last step](https://gitlab.com/invent-analytics/optimization/enigma/-/blob/master/Jenkinsfile#L95) of Enigma master branch build. In rocket dag, the pre-installed `enigma.problem.allocation.allocation` module is [triggered](https://gitlab.com/invent-analytics/pipeline/spider/-/blob/master/dags/spider/spider_rocket_daily.py#L607)as optimization task. Due to the fact that optimization user is currently one and the only user for optimization task in all clients, we are not able to work with different versions of rocket-rocks-enigma combinations among clients.

Failure point

le to work with different versions of rocket-rocks-enigma combinations among clients.

Failure point

Because of the internal packages are installed into gurobi-server in enigma build, merge requests in enigma repo should be merged after the success builds of rocket and warp master branches. Otherwise, gurobi server may have the latest enigma version, but at the same time may have the old versions of rocket or warp.

As mentioned in this article before, current pyspark-based structure of rocks is the main reason why optimization module is in enigma repo now. So, there will be no other obstacle to move enigma module into rocks.

## Overview

Our software is built around the data. It means, the interaction between software and human intelligence creates the value. In other words, operationalizing the domain knowledge of humans with software generates value.

A data-driven software consists of "pipelines." Each pipeline step performs operations like data transformation, feature engineering, modeling, optimization, and reporting. Operationalization of these consist of the following steps:

- Develop
- Test
- Version
- Deploy
- Monitor

This is a continuous process. Meaning, we need to continuously develop, test and deploy new versions of the software, and monitor events and metrics in real-time. Experimenting with new ideas, testing them and deploying them to the production should be one click away.

imenting with new ideas, testing them and deploying them to the production should be one click away.

What makes this process hard is the multi-dimensional nature of the problem. We are not operationalizing code and infrastructure only. Data, features, models, and pipelines should be operationalized as well. Each of these should have its own developing, testing, versioning, deploying, and monitoring solutions. We will call this end-to-end process MLOps.

### Two-Legged Architecture

, and monitoring solutions. We will call this end-to-end process MLOps.

### Two-Legged Architecture

We should not design our architecture only for automation through software. Human interaction is another important aspect of our work. We are constantly tracking KPIs and experimenting with new models and deploy them to the production. This makes MLOps a two-legged architecture, one is operations, the other one is analytics. The operations leg should be solid enough to work by itself and open to extensions introduced by human intelligence. Analytics and operations, humans and software should be able to work on the same ground, with the same tools.

### Challenges

humans and software should be able to work on the same ground, with the same tools.

### Challenges

In traditional software engineering, we assume that the code and data are separated. However, a machine learning system is a mixture of these two. For example, we only focus on testing and versioning code in traditional software. In machine learning systems, we have to test and version the data as well. Here are some challenges that we face while developing machine learning software:

the data as well. Here are some challenges that we face while developing machine learning software:

- Data versioning: How to checkpoint the different states of data? Can you move to a previous state if new data worsen your output?
- Data testing: How to test the quality of the data? Does it satisfy your expectations?
- Data monitoring: How to detect the changes in the data? Are there any shifts in distribution?
- Model versioning: How to keep track of the changes in a model? Which model is in production?
- Model testing: How to make sure a model produces better results before going into production?
- Model monitoring: How to continuously monitor the quality of your model? Do existing models still produce good results? Do you need to retrain?
- Model serving: How to use a model in production? Is it scaleable?

### Components

need to retrain?
- Model serving: How to use a model in production? Is it scaleable?

### Components

Every challenge mentioned requires its unique solution. For this, we will summarize some of the frequently used components in the MLOps literature and their benefits. Later, we should write separate PIPs for each of these parts.

#### Data

This component is responsible for making the data transparent, accessible, and validated. Meaning, all agents in the system, including humans and machines, can browse the data catalog, find what she is looking for, and ensure the data quality is good.

Think this as:

- a search engine that we and our codes can use to find a data
- a monitoring and alerting tool that constantly informs us about the quality of the data
- an information center that we can find statistics, ownership and lineage informations, etc. about a dataset

#### Feature

that we can find statistics, ownership and lineage informations, etc. about a dataset

#### Feature

Features are hard. One can find herself in a situation that maintaining hundreds of features. We are doing this by maintaining one-single-giant-features-table. This makes our lives harder when we want to:

- add/remove a feature
- backfill the history of a feature
- generate point-in-time training sets using those features
- monitor the quality of the features

A feature store is a central location for all features that we can use for training a model, and a computation engine that computes the correct values for the desired features for a given training time and prediction period.

#### Model

correct values for the desired features for a given training time and prediction period.

#### Model

We train models and save their artifacts somewhere. It’s hard to know which features and datasets are used, how does this model performs, how to use it in production. In a model registry, we can find all meta information such as features, data, training periods, historic performance, benchmarking against other models etc.

Model deployment process is different than code deployment. We would like to deploy models even though we did not deploy code. Model registry helps us a lot when we want to deploy a model to production. Once we register our models, we can compare them and select the one to be used in production.

#### Metadata

This is needed for mainly two reasons: indexing, and communicating.

d in production.

#### Metadata

This is needed for mainly two reasons: indexing, and communicating.

For example, a data scientist wants to get all tables that has a specific column. She can read all tables and check that the column she is looking for is there. But, this approach is costly, in terms of time and computation. Another approach would be saving these kind of information as metadata and use it as an index.

Another example would be the communication between systems. Think of a prediction service that makes predictions with latest trained model. How can it find the latest model? Maybe we can use a configuration file. What happens a new model trained then? Instead, prediction service can ask for the latest model to the metadata service, without human interaction or configuration.

There might be alternative solutions for these problems, but, using a metadata service reduces the amount of work required, and makes MLOps components transparent and accessible.

Testing

reduces the amount of work required, and makes MLOps components transparent and accessible.

Testing

This not an actual component. But it is so important that we need to consider it as a component. We are familiar with the traditional software testing approach. We have unit tests, integration tests, etc. However, these approaches were designed for code. We need new ways of testing the data and models as well. We can test the new-coming data and see how it affects the output. Every trained model should be tested before going into production.

### Result

Our "self-driving" analytics approach requires operational efficiency and excellence. We want good output quality, fast onboarding, and scalability with minimum effort. To achieve such excellence, we should embrace the best practices of the industry as a company. As a next step, we should write detailed follow-up PIPs to address the challenges mentioned above.

, we should write detailed follow-up PIPs to address the challenges mentioned above.

## Benefits

Some benefits of delta data format over parquet:

- At the core, it is parquetProvides the benefits of parquet out-of-box
- Single data storage for all kinds of workNo X-to-Y data transition jobs. Everyone will use the same data (ad-hoc analysis, production jobs, tableau reports, UI)
- Provides database like capabilitiesSchema protectionUpdates, merges, deletes
- FasterNo storage directory scans for data discovery. File locations are stored as metadata.Fast merges and deletes
- VersioningWe can track how the data changesGo back to a specific version when needed (when the data is accidentally deleted for example)
- Time travelMove between versions
- MetadataStores metadata by default. Good for data browsing and storing column stats.

## Motivation

Rocks library is a heavily configured and customized product. However, different namespaces have different conventions and this situation makes it harder to use. Therefore, we should develop a unified config management approach to provide stable and user friendly configuration.

## What problem does it solve?

The most important problem that can be solved by a new Config System in rocks is having an unified configuration approach. So, one should simply use same structure of config files at every single part of the application.

h. So, one should simply use same structure of config files at every single part of the application.

The other problem that will be solved is Config Validation. Currently, all subpackages of rocks handle their own validation logic and write plenty of code to apply some schema and content based validation. We should have reusable validators that can validate the input configuration.

Additionally, it is often confusing what is a configuration element and what is a runtime application argument element. We should simplify this ambiguity and treat them similarly.

## Why is this change needed?

To make rocks more stable and user-friendly, we should have a solid config system. So, we should implement a stable config system, and all product teams should use it. With the help of a solid config system:

a stable config system, and all product teams should use it. With the help of a solid config system:

- It will be clear what a pipeline step expects as config, including the data types and business validation cases.
- It will be easier to maintain domain specific configuration.
- It will be more structured to change config on client side for Data Scientists using any product (i.e. noob, rocket etc.).
- It will be easier to validate configs.

## Suggested Implementation

### Specification

The suggested implementation built on top of the following:

ested Implementation

### Specification

The suggested implementation built on top of the following:

- Config values should be typed.
- Config model should be defined within the PipelineStep module that uses the config.
- PipelineStep should be responsible of complex validation logic and specify its business needs. However, simple validations such as type-checks should be commonly handled.
- Application arguments should override config values.
- It is not a common pattern to base PipelineStep classes from ConfigModel classes, as most of them behave like data-classes but PipelineStep classes implement a business logic. Therefore, we should provide an abstraction level for Config Model classes and make our system independent of third party config validation libraries.
- Config will be independent of class/module hierarchy. Config will be accessed with section names.
- It is alright to use multiple files for configuration, but we should specify the namespaces.

ames.
- It is alright to use multiple files for configuration, but we should specify the namespaces.

As stated above, we should have pre-determined config namespaces and a few config files for those namespaces. The pre-determined namespaces are stated as below:

- run_environment: containing information regarding to the environment where run take place (e.g. bucket_name, storage_type, pokedex_cloud_provider, customer_name etc)
- metadata: metadata information regarding to tables or anything else on a schemaless format, similar to Pokedex
- feature_flags: a mapping to manage feature flags
- noob: noob namespace
- rocket: rocket namespace
- opal: opal namespace

### File Structure

Considering the namespaces above, following file structure can be followed in both rocks library and client side.

he namespaces above, following file structure can be followed in both rocks library and client side.

```
rocks
-- config.yaml: base config to maintain the namespaces and common variables
-- noob
---- config.yaml
---- metadata.yaml
-- rocket
---- config.yaml
---- metadata.yaml
-- opal
---- config.yaml
---- metadata.yaml
```

### High Level Class Design

Below, a high level class diagram for a config system is depicted.

Following proposes a module structure:

```
configuration/
-- load.py
---- ConfigLoader
-- merge.py
---- ConfigMerge
-- serve.py
---- ConfigServe
-- config_types.py
-- base.py
```

### How to find which files should be read?

Currently, only one config file is being read, or @provide_config decorator finds config files to load based on module structure. As we have domain based pre-determined config files, we can write a specification file that defines config files each namespace requires and their merge order.

write a specification file that defines config files each namespace requires and their merge order.

    ]

```

In the example above, `CONFIG_SPEC["noob"]` returns us the config files noob should load. Assume that `CLIENT_CONFIG_FOLDER = "rocks_extension/config"`, the file structure will be as shown below:

```
[
    [
        "rocks/config.yaml",
        "rocks/noob/metadata.yaml"
        "rocks/noob/config.yaml",
    ],
    [
        "rocks_extension/config/config.yaml",
        "rocks_extension/config/noob/metadata.yaml"
        "rocks_extension/config/noob/config.yaml",
    ]
]
```

Here, firstly, `rocks/config.yaml`, `rocks/noob/metadata.yaml, rocks/noob/config.yaml`  will be merged where the last one has the highest priority. After, client side config files will be merged. Finally, both will be merged. By this way, client configuration will have priority over library.

### Config Flow in the system

### Challenges

There are two major challenges on this topic:

1. Products have to adjust their configuration in the rocks library
2. Client side config should be migrated to the new system as they reach to use recent rocks versions after this change is deployed.

### Usability

New config system can be used via a mixin class, ConfigMixin. This class is responsible of accepting the name of config namespace to be used, and name of config section to be resolved. Then, it injects the config values to the corresponding class. The user module class should define its attributes which will be obtained from config and injected.

```
class ConfigMixin:
    def __init__(config_section, config_namespace, kwargs):
      self.config_section = config_section
      self.config_namespace = config_namespace
      # let them be injected
      super().__init__(config)

class FooModule(BasePipelineStep, ConfigMixin):

    config_key_x: str = StringType()

nit__(config)

class FooModule(BasePipelineStep, ConfigMixin):

    config_key_x: str = StringType()

    def __init__(kwargs):
        super().__init__(kwargs)
```

### Backward Compatibility

This suggestion is not necessarily have to be backward compatible. In fact, all config system should be built on top of this approach on both library and client side. But if we have to make it backward compatible, we can manage it with an environment variable

```
ROCKS_CONFIG_SYSTEM = os.environ.get("ROCKS_CONFIG_SYSTEM") == "new"

class FooModule(BasePipelineStep, ConfigMixin if ROCKS_CONFIG_SYSTEM else object):
  def __init__(kwargs):
      super().__init__(kwargs)
      if not ROCKS_CONFIG_SYSTEM:
          self.config = get_config_in_old_way(kwargs)
```

### Considered Alternatives / Rejected Ideas

#### Hierarchical Config Based on Module Hierarchy

This idea is based on building a config system based on module hierarchy, where nested config sections are parallel to the module and the class. For example, “DailyData” class in “rocks.noob.daily_data” module should have the config hierarchy as below:

```
rocks:
  noob:
    daily_data:
      DailyData:
        config_key_x: config_value_x
```

This is rejected because it introduces a weak reference to the code, exposing the internal structure to no-code environment, and all client config would have to change if class name is changed.

Config Model class with Inheritance

This idea is based on building parallel model classes for config, and use them with inheritance.

ce

This idea is based on building parallel model classes for config, and use them with inheritance.

```
class FooConfigModel:
   config_key_x: str

class FooModule(FooConfigModel):
```

This idea is rejected because it may be harder for to extend rocks classes in terms of config when there’s a need to add a new config key.

#### Config as container object with Composition over Inheritance

This idea is based on building parallel model classes for config, and use them as container objects within the module.

```
class FooConfigModel:
   config_key_x: str

class FooModule:
    def __init__(self):
        self.config = FooConfigModel(config_args)
```

This idea is rejected because it may be harder for to extend rocks classes in terms of config when there’s a need to add a new config key. Additionally, using a container object for config and handling application arguments separately would not help us reduce application argument / config ambiguity
